text: New: WH statement on delivery of Mueller Report: "The next steps are up to Attorney General Barr, and we look forward to the process taking its course. The White House has not received or been briefed on the Special Counsel’s report." -- Sarah Sanders
author: christinawilkie

text: Moore's comments were also prescient back in July 2016. He described how Trump's message on trade and immigration was appealing to a new coalition of working class voters who had not voted Republican in 2012.
author: christinawilkie

text: Commerce and Energy Depts are Moore's betes noires. "As for Commerce, I call it the department of corporate welfare," he said. “I mean, my God, why do we need an Energy Department? All the Energy Department has done in the last 25 years is make energy prices more expensive!”
author: christinawilkie

text: In 2016, I reported what Stephen Moore told a mtg of the secretive Council for National Policy. Moore called for eliminating the Departments of Commerce, Education and Energy, ending TANF and offering rust-belt workers new jobs on oil rigs. Audio here:
author: christinawilkie

text: Putin has boasted that the missile is superior to any ever built. But the longest test flight lasted only 2 minutes before the missile lost control and crashed. Shortest test lasted 4 seconds. US intel sources tell @CNBC they don't think it'll be operational for at least 10 yrs.
author: christinawilkie

text: BRK: Putin's hypersonic nuclear missile with 'unlimited' range is too expensive to develop and has yet to fly farther than 22 miles, U.S. intelligence sources tell @amanda_m_macias
author: christinawilkie

text: NEW: Several major Dem donors have told Joe Biden they won't raise money for him early on in his expected 2020 run. "I told him I can donate, but I don't want to give chits today for Joe. What's my benefit?" one such donor said to @SchwartzBCNBC
author: christinawilkie

text: SCOOP by ⁦@kaylatausche:⁩ Trump wants China to raise its offer to buy US goods in order to strike a trade deal, sources say.
author: christinawilkie

text: Not surprisingly, the White House then pushed out the talking points/op-ed as a press release.
author: christinawilkie

text: The New York Times ran an op-ed today by Trump trade adviser Peter Navarro that sounds an awful lot like the talking points a senior Trump admin official read out yesterday on a press call about Trump's Ohio trip.
author: christinawilkie

text: The million dollar accounting error is messy, but answerable. The real test will be whether Revuilding America Now ever responds to the letter asking how Laury Gay chalked up $149,000 in unitemized “travel” expenses after the PAC had been dormant for a year.
author: christinawilkie

text: Thanks Tommy!
author: christinawilkie

text: NEW: Joe Biden, all but certain to run for President, is concerned he won’t garner the millions in online donations that Beto O’Rourke and Bernie Sanders pulled in when they announced. Great scoop from ⁦@EmilyGlazer⁩ and ⁦@KThomasDC⁩
author: christinawilkie

text: Looking forward to joining the awesome Chris Hayes tonight on @allinwithchris to talk Michael Cohen, Russian oligarchs and what we learned from today's newly released documents.
author: christinawilkie

text: Great detail here: "Sirota said he hadn’t been able to respond to my initial inquiries Monday because he’d been caring for his sick child. He did post a photo on Twitter of himself bowling on Monday evening, wearing a turkey hat." By @IsaacDovere
author: christinawilkie

text: Bernie Sanders' newest speechwriter @DavidSirota deleted 20,000 tweets after being contacted by @isaacdovere about his months of secret work as a Sanders adviser while at the same time using his Guardian column to savage Sanders' Democratic opponents.
author: christinawilkie

text:

text:
Trump: "I have many many millions of followers on @Twitter, and it's different than it used to be. Things are happening. Names are being taken off. If they're conservative or Republicans, it's big big discrimination. 

"There is collusion. Because something has to be going on."
author: christinawilkie

text: Brazilian President Bolsonaro says Brazil and United States stand together for "traditional family lifestyles" and "against fake news."
author: christinawilkie

text: New: Two shadows loom over today's Trump/Bolsonaro talks: One is cast by China, Brazil's biggest trading partner and Trump's international bete noire. The other belongs to Steve Bannon, godfather of both Trump's and Bolsonaro's isolationist worldviews
author: christinawilkie

text: Thank you so much!
author: christinawilkie

text: That doc I pasted is 269 pages long, so just click it. The redaction starts on page 38.
author: christinawilkie

text: The 18 redacted pages titled "The Illegal Campaign Contribution Scheme" could prove decisive if Trump is ever prosecuted. And 18 is a loaded number in the history of presidential misdeeds. Nixon's infamous missing Watergate tape was exactly 18 minutes.
author: christinawilkie

text: BRK: All the applications and exhibits FBI agents used to get search warrants for Michael Cohen's home, office, and hotel room. 835 pages total, read 'em here >>>
author: christinawilkie

text: At the request of Times readers, a chess coach at PS 116 has set up a go fund me page for those who want to help Tanitoluwa and his parents secure a permanent home.
author: christinawilkie

text:
An 8 year old homeless refugee from Nigeria has been crowned New York State chess champion for K - 3rd grade.

Tanitoluwa Adewumi’s story reminds us that despite huge opportunity gaps, America is filled with talent, much of it contributed by immigrants.
author: christinawilkie

text: twitter, how do I temporarily banish all tweets that are more than 50 seconds old, and all tweets that aren't Judge Jackson quotes. Thanks.
author: christinawilkie

text:
This is notable bc a lot of Manafort's defense against these particular charges was centered  on the idea that Manafort was confused, unaware of what he was doing, or didn't know it was illegal.  

ABJ saying she doesn't buy this.
author: christinawilkie

text: ABJ directly counters the "blameless life" hypothesis.
author: christinawilkie

text:
Judge ABJ: “It's hard to overstate the number of lies" Manafort told. Notes he's still not being straight w the court about witness tampering. "Court is one of those places where facts still matter."

For more on those lies, see my thread (it's a little too long, I know) below.
author: christinawilkie

text: Seems Paul Manafort is not the only member of Trumpland who's having a bad week in court. Rudy Giuliani angered the judge presiding over his divorce.
author: christinawilkie

text: Literally every criminal ever convicted, ever, could have legitimately and truthfully said to the judge at trial, "But for ____________, I don't think we'd be here today."
author: christinawilkie

text:
If you want to read how this all played out in court, here's a good transcript. 
https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/5731934-USA-v-Manafort-2-4-19-Hearing-Redacted-Transcript.html …

My story on all this should help you fill in the redacted names. https://www.cnbc.com/2019/03/10/paul-manafort-lawyer-mysterious-payment-hidden-chapter-of-trump-2016-campaign.html … 

/END
author: christinawilkie

text:
And now here we are, with example number ten million in American politics of the cover-up becoming worse than the crime.  

Meanwhile, neither ABJ nor the prosecutors really seemed to care about some defunct super PAC's backroom commission deal.  11/
author: christinawilkie

text:
Best part of all is that none of the shenanigans at the super PAC would have ever come to light if Manafort had just said, "yeah, there was a commission split deal, and here's how it worked." 

Instead, he lied. And when he got caught, he lied again. And then he lied again. 10/
author: christinawilkie

text: Per prosecutors, the fact that records have Manafort calling Gay first for the $125,000, and sending Gay the wiring instructions, not Fabrizio, strongly suggests that Manafort was aware of the kickback scheme, and that he and Gay had their own "commission split" going. 9/
author: christinawilkie

text:
The whole time Manafort was telling the Fabrizio versions, he knew prosecutors had texts where Manafort instructs Gay where to wire the money. 

But if this were really a loan from his old pal TF, why would Manafort send wiring instructions to a totally unrelated 3rd person? 8/
author: christinawilkie

text:
Again, Fabrizio denies it. Says, I didn't loan Paul any money. In fact, he adds, when Manafort hit him up for a contribution to Manafort's defense fund, Fabrizio turned him down.  

Again, why Manafort told a story that relied on the other guy to back him up is inexplicable. 7/
author: christinawilkie

text:
OK, so then Manafort goes to story #3, which is that the $125,000 was a loan from Fabrizio to Manafort, a personal loan from a fried, at which point Manafort produced an unsigned, random one page supposed loan agreement. 

Again, totally different story than the previous two. 6/
author: christinawilkie

text: But this story wasn't true because Fabrizio immediately told prosecutors the money he sent to Manafort's lawyers wasn't payment to Manafort for anything, it was part of Gay's share of their secret "commission split" arrangement, and Gay had told him where to send it. 5/
author: christinawilkie

text: Story #2. The money was income, paid to him by Fabrizio, essentially it was Manafort's long lost cut of the proceeds from business he sent Fabrizio's firms over the years. His finders fee, if you will. This version is also what Manafort told his accountant in 2017. 4/
author: christinawilkie

text: Story #1. The money came from Gay, repayment of a debt that Gay owed Manafort. This was false because the money didn't come from Gay, it came from Fabrizio's ad buying firm, whose name never surfaced in this version of the story. 3/
author: christinawilkie

text: They weren't a story that kept changing, they were totally unrelated stories, and he seemed unaware that each new one made his last statement completely false, not just a little false. 2/
author: christinawilkie

text:
Prosecutor just reminded ABJ that Manafort made "false statements to the FBI and false statements to the grand jury repeatedly." 

This was one of the strangest things about the $125,000 payment I dug into: Each of Manafort's 3 lies about the $$ was totally new.  1/
author: christinawilkie

author: christinawilkie

text: Rebuilding America Now all but disappeared last fall. Its last Tweet was posted on Oct 10 2018. This was 10 days after Manafort told his 2nd alleged lie about the $125,000. Its website was removed sometime last fall. A Facebook page still links to the nonexistent website. /END
author: christinawilkie

text: Gay's total, $924,164 is very close to the $925,000 combined total that Fabrizio's firm MMSC transferred to Rebuilding America Now and Manafort's lawyers in May and June 2017. ($800,000 in "reimbursements" to the PAC plus $125,000 to Manafort's lawyers = $925K). Very close.
author: christinawilkie

text:
Another strange confluence: After the 2016 election, Rebuilding America Now essentially went dormant. But Laurance Gay continued to collect $35K a month plus huge travel expenses for another year and a half. 

Gay's total fees and expenses AFTER the election total $924,164.03.
author: christinawilkie

text: The cash transfers were reported to the FEC as reimbursements for ad money not spent. But political ad buyers told me this is not what reimbursements look like. Typically they're very precise amounts, paid out right after an election. Not a flat sum of $800K paid 6 months later.
author: christinawilkie

text:
Another strange set of events. In May 2017, long after the election, MMSC, Fabrizio's firm, made three large cash transfers to Rebuilding America Now.
May 27 for $150,000
June 15 for $625,000
June 16 for $25,000 
And then 10 days later, MMSC paid Manafort's lawyers $125,000.
author: christinawilkie

text: Rebuilding America Now paid Fabrizio's firm MMSC unusually high commission rates on ad buys, so high that PAC donors actually questioned them in 2016. Now we know why: Fabrizio and Laurance Gay had a secret commission split arrangement: 6% rate was paid to MMSC, and Gay got 3%.
author: christinawilkie

text: According to court transcripts and Mueller case filings, Fabrizio appears to have told Mueller that in order to get his firm, MMSC hired as the ad buyer for Rebuilding America Now, he had to agree to secretly split the commission with Laurance Gay, a longtime Manafort associate.
author: christinawilkie

text: Tony Fabrizio's dual role as: a) the owner of MMSC, which was the biggest vendor by far to the top pro-Trump super PAC, Rebuilding America Now, and b)  his job as the Trump campaign's lead pollster, has not been reported until now.
author: christinawilkie
